Holy Catholic Church

"Its Continuity in England."

A Lecture delivered by the Bishop of Quilipglo, Jan. 28.

Consider from the point of view of the Church at large, what is the present condition of the Church in England? It seems evident that there is a great deal of confusion and division within the Church. The question arises whether the Church in England is still a true continuation of the primitive Church. The Bishop of Quilipglo addressed a lecture on this topic, emphasizing the importance of maintaining the continuity of the Church.

The lecture discussed various aspects of the Church's history, including the role of bishops and the importance of preserving the traditions of the Church. The Bishop highlighted the need for unity and cooperation among members of the Church, especially in times of division and confusion.

Throughout the lecture, the Bishop emphasized the importance of maintaining the integrity of the Church's teachings and practices. He encouraged listeners to reflect on their own faith and to strive for greater understanding and communion within the Church.

In conclusion, the Bishop called upon all members of the Church to work together to maintain its continuity and to preserve its rich traditions. He reminded listeners of the importance of faithfulness to the teachings of Christ and the Apostles, and urged them to remain steadfast in their commitment to the Church.

This lecture serves as a reminder of the ongoing challenges faced by the Church today, and the importance of maintaining its continuity and integrity in the face of these challenges.
OUR TERMS.

We have placed our yearly subscription at the low rate of ONE DOLLAR, with the object of enforcing and securing payment. We can much better afford to publish a paper at that price when we know that every paper going out is paid for, than if we took the chances of collecting accounts at a higher figure. Besides, we will at once be able to secure a larger circulation, which will enhance the value of our advertising columns. So dear reader send us your name and a dollar, and get your neighbor to subscribe, and you will obtain full value for your money in interesting reading from now till January 1st, 1887.

Mr. Andrew Patterson, manager of the climatic factory, has written as follows in the Rapid City Examiner, June 19th:

"A large number of letters and reports concerning the new factory have been received. I am pleased to inform you that the business conducted by the company is in every respect satisfactory. The house is now well furnished with machines and everything necessary for the comfort of the tenants. The climate is agreeable and the air is wholesome.

"The company is pleased to inform you that they have employed a number of women to assist in the work. The wages are fair and the conditions of employment are favorable.

"I would like to urge upon you the importance of joining the company and enjoying the benefits of the new factory."

Subscription Office

Subscription Office, Rapid City, does not make any claims for the quality or authenticity of Mr. Patterson's letter. They offer their condolences to anyone who may have been affected by the contents of his message.

**HOME & GOSPEL**

**GUADALUPE**

Moral item first page

The Regina presbytery meets here Monday next.

Remember the March monthly fires to be held here Saturday March 9th.

May, Johnson and Garrell's second attempt takes place tomorrow evening.

Rev. J. Peck will occupy the Methodist pulpit here next Sunday evening; Mr. H. Lawson will be in Moosejaw.

Capt. Wm. Clark, Government Grain Inspector, has been sent north to inspect the Saskatcheewan settlers.

Mr. B. Lamberton, has secured some land from the Indians north of Qu'Appelle river with wheat.

Fire prevention means a plenty of firewood must be available; this should receive the attention of the meeting this evening.

Fear that fire teams are not on duty, or that the men have abandoned their stations, for the purpose of fighting from this point north.

The new North of Scotland Loyal Corps, was in town this week. He was one of several bands who played on Monday.

On Monday Miss Flora Grivie, one of the school children, fell into the well near the church Sunday afternoon for about three minutes; she appeared to be unconscious for a number of seconds after regaining consciousness.

It has been decided to forward firewood to all the villages of the settlement for the purpose of fighting from this point north.

The Deputy Inspector of the North of Scotland Loyal Corps, was in town this week. He was one of several bands who played on Monday.

Attention is directed to the ad-

vertised sale this Friday. Wright Sons, in another column,

This proposal is proper for sale at the present moment, but will be made at no time in the future until a large sum of money is raised by the trust farmers and others in the village who will follow the example set by this firm in endeavoring to make this fair a success.

We notice a decided improvement in the singing of the English church school last two of the Sundays. This should encourage the parents to give the best portion of their attention in their efforts towards making the service worthy of their beautiful church and in all order with our beloved Bishop. The resultant of this combination only will ensure this.

On Saturday last a matched skiff race took place between Qu'Appelle lake, between the villages of Indian Head and this place resulted in the victory of this side by a margin of six to seven yards. The races were:

**SCHOOL DISTRICT OF SUMMERBURY**

Protestant Public School District No. 36 of the N.W. Territory.

**Special Public Meeting**

To elect directors of the summer district to be held at noon March 8th.

FRIDAY MARCH 12, 1886.

For the purpose of taking a vote on the question of electing directors of the special summer district to be held at noon March 8th.

The resolutions adopted at the school board meeting of March 8th.

---

**JAMES H. LOWE**, School Board of Directors.

Printed at Summerbury, the eighth day of February, 1889.
